verb.description: Diminish or destroy the value or quality of.
examples: I wouldn't want to spoil your fun
a series of political blunders spoiled their chances of being re-elected

verb.description: Harm the character of (someone, especially a child) by being too lenient or indulgent.
examples: the last thing I want to do is spoil Thomas

verb.description: Be extremely or aggressively eager for.
examples: Cooper was spoiling for a fight

verb.description: Rob (a person or a place) of goods or possessions by force or violence.

noun.description: Goods stolen or taken forcibly from a person or place.
examples: the looters carried their spoils away

noun.description: Waste material brought up during the course of an excavation or a dredging or mining operation.

origin: Middle English (in the sense to plunder): shortening of Old French espoille (noun), espoillier (verb), from Latin spoliare, from spolium plunder, skin stripped from an animal, or a shortening of despoil.
